docs.title: Welcome to Linux Notes
docs.text:
1. File & Directory - Explore the essentials of file and directory management, including commands for creating, deleting, and navigating the file system.
    • File and Directory Management - Detailed guide on managing files and directories effectively using various Linux commands.
    • File Permissions - Learn how to manage file permissions to control access and secure your files.
    • File Viewing and Editing - Techniques and tools for viewing and editing files in Linux.
  2. Firewall & Networking - Comprehensive guide on setting up and managing firewalls and network configurations.
    • Firewalls and Networking - Detailed guide on managing firewalls and network connections.
    • Network Configuration and Monitoring - Understand network configurations and how to monitor network activity and performance.
    • SSH - Secure Shell (SSH) guide for remote login and secure communication over unsecured networks.
  3. System Management - Learn about system monitoring, process management, and performance tuning to maintain a healthy Linux environment.
    • System Information - Retrieve and interpret various system information and hardware details.
    • Disk Management - Learn about managing disks, partitions, and filesystems in Linux.
    • User and Group Management - Manage users and groups, including creation, deletion, and permission settings.
    • Package Management - Manage software packages, including installation, updates, and removal.
    • Process Management - Learn about monitoring and controlling processes in Linux.
  4. Editors - Get familiar with popular text editors in Linux, their features, and how to use them effectively for various tasks.
    • Editor - Nano - A beginner-friendly, easy-to-use text editor for quick edits and simple tasks.
    • Editor - Vim - A powerful and highly configurable text editor with a steep learning curve but extensive capabilities.
    • Editor - Gedit - A simple and intuitive graphical text editor, suitable for everyday use.

docs.title: Editors
docs.text:
Get familiar with popular text editors in Linux, their features, and how to use them effectively for various tasks.

  • Nano - A beginner-friendly, easy-to-use text editor for quick edits and simple tasks.
  • Vim - A powerful and highly configurable text editor with a steep learning curve but extensive capabilities.
  • Gedit - A simple and intuitive graphical text editor, suitable for everyday use.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: gedit is a simple text editor for the GNOME desktop environment. It is known for its ease of use and is suitable for editing text files, programming scripts, and more. This document covers basic gedit commands and operations.

docs.title: Open a File
docs.text:
To open a file with gedit, use the following command:

gedit <file_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
gedit example.txt
# Opens 'example.txt' in gedit

docs.title: Create a New File
docs.text:
To create a new file, simply open gedit without specifying a file name:

gedit

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
gedit
# Opens a new, untitled document in gedit

docs.title: Save Changes
docs.text:
To save changes to a file, use the graphical interface:

  1. Click File > Save or press Ctrl + S.
  2. Choose the file name and location, then click Save.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Make edits to the document.
  2. Press Ctrl + S to save.

docs.title: Save As
docs.text:
To save the file with a new name or location:

  1. Click File > Save As... or press Ctrl + Shift + S.
  2. Enter the new file name and location, then click Save.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Click File > Save As....
  2. Enter a new name like newfile.txt and select the location.
  3. Click Save.

docs.title: Undo and Redo
docs.text:
To undo or redo changes:

  • Undo: Ctrl + Z
  • Redo: Ctrl + Y

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Press Ctrl + Z to undo the last action
# Press Ctrl + Y to redo the action

docs.title: Search for Text
docs.text:
To search for text within the file:

  1. Press Ctrl + F.
  2. Enter the search term and press Enter.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + F.
  2. Type search_term and press Enter.

docs.title: Replace Text
docs.text:
To replace text within the file:

  1. Press Ctrl + H.
  2. Enter the search term and the replacement term.
  3. Click Replace or Replace All.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + H.
  2. Enter old_term in the search box and new_term in the replace box.
  3. Click Replace or Replace All.

docs.title: Open Multiple Files
docs.text:
To open multiple files at once, list them after the gedit command:

gedit file1.txt file2.txt

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
gedit file1.txt file2.txt
# Opens 'file1.txt' and 'file2.txt' in separate tabs

docs.title: Open Files from a Directory
docs.text:
To open all text files in a directory:

gedit /path/to/directory/*.txt

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
gedit /home/user/documents/*.txt
# Opens all '.txt' files in the '/home/user/documents' directory

docs.title: Open Files with Specific Encoding
docs.text:
To open a file with a specific encoding, use the --encoding option:

gedit --encoding <encoding> <file_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
gedit --encoding utf-8 example.txt
# Opens 'example.txt' with UTF-8 encoding

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: gedit is a versatile text editor with a straightforward graphical interface. It allows for simple text editing tasks such as creating, opening, saving, and searching files. For more detailed information and options, refer to the gedit documentation or the GNOME Help.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: nano is a simple and user-friendly text editor for the command line. It is often used for editing configuration files and scripting. This document provides a guide to common nano commands and operations.

docs.title: Open a File
docs.text:
To open a file in nano, simply specify the file name.

nano <file_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nano example.txt
# Opens 'example.txt' in the nano editor

docs.title: Save Changes
docs.text: To save changes while editing, press Ctrl + O (Write Out), then press Enter to confirm the file name.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Edit the file.
  2. Press Ctrl + O.
  3. Press Enter.

docs.title: Exit nano
docs.text: To exit nano, press Ctrl + X. If you have unsaved changes, nano will prompt you to save them.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + X.
  2. If prompted to save changes, press Y (Yes) or N (No).

docs.title: Cut Text
docs.text: To cut text, use Ctrl + K. This will cut the current line or selected text.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Place the cursor on the line you want to cut.
  2. Press Ctrl + K.
  3. The line will be removed and stored in the clipboard.

docs.title: Paste Text
docs.text: To paste text that was cut or copied, use Ctrl + U.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Move the cursor to the location where you want to paste.
  2. Press Ctrl + U.

docs.title: Copy Text
docs.text: To copy text, use Ctrl + ^ to set the mark, move the cursor to select the text, and then press Ctrl + K to cut. Paste it using Ctrl + U.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + ^ to set the mark.
  2. Move the cursor to select the text.
  3. Press Ctrl + K to cut the selected text.
  4. Move the cursor to the paste location.
  5. Press Ctrl + U to paste.

docs.title: Search for Text
docs.text: To search for text within the file, press Ctrl + W (Where Is), then enter the search term and press Enter.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + W.
  2. Enter the search term.
  3. Press Enter.

docs.title: Replace Text
docs.text: To replace text, press Ctrl + \ (Replace), then enter the search term, press Enter, enter the replacement term, and press Enter.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + \.
  2. Enter the search term.
  3. Press Enter.
  4. Enter the replacement term.
  5. Press Enter.

docs.title: Go to Line Number
docs.text: To move the cursor to a specific line number, press Ctrl + _ (Underscore), enter the line number, and press Enter.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + _.
  2. Enter the line number (e.g., 10).
  3. Press Enter.

docs.title: Show Line Numbers
docs.text: To enable line numbers, press Ctrl + C to view the current line number, or check the status bar for line numbers.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
1. Press Ctrl + C to view the current line number.
  2. Check the status bar at the bottom of the editor.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: nano is a powerful yet easy-to-use text editor that allows you to efficiently edit files from the command line. Understanding these basic commands will help you navigate and modify files effectively. For more detailed information, refer to the nano man pages by running man nano in the terminal.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: vim (Vi IMproved) is a powerful text editor in Linux with extensive features for editing text files. This document covers essential vim commands and operations to help you get started.

docs.title: Opening a File
docs.text:
To open a file with vim, use the following command:

vim <file_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
vim example.txt
# Opens 'example.txt' in vim

docs.title: vim Modes
docs.text:
vim operates in different modes, primarily:

  • Normal Mode: For navigation and command execution (default mode when vim starts).
  • Insert Mode: For text insertion.
  • Visual Mode: For selecting text.
  • Command-Line Mode: For executing commands (entered by pressing : in Normal Mode).

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
• Move Cursor: h (left), j (down), k (up), l (right)
  • Move by Words: w (forward), b (backward)
  • Move to Line Start/End: 0 (start), $ (end)
  • Move to Specific Line: :n (where n is the line number)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Move cursor to the 10th line
:10

docs.title: Deleting Text
docs.text:
• Delete Character: x
  • Delete Line: dd
  • Delete Word: dw
  • Delete to End of Line: d$

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Delete the current line
dd

docs.title: Copying and Pasting
docs.text:
• Copy Line: yy
  • Paste: p

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Copy the current line and paste it below
yy
p

docs.title: Undo and Redo
docs.text:
• Undo: u
  • Redo: Ctrl + r

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Undo the last change
u

docs.title: Entering Insert Mode
docs.text:
• Insert Before Cursor: i
  • Insert After Cursor: a
  • Append After Line: A
  • Insert New Line: o (below), O (above)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Enter Insert Mode and type text
iHello, World!

docs.title: Exiting Insert Mode
docs.text: • Return to Normal Mode: Esc

docs.title: Example
docs.text: # Press Esc to return to Normal Mode

docs.title: Selecting Text
docs.text:
• Enter Visual Mode: v
  • Select Whole Line: V
  • Select Block: Ctrl + v

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Enter Visual Mode and select text
v

docs.title: Copying and Pasting in Visual Mode
docs.text:
• Copy: y (after selection)
  • Paste: p (after selection)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Select text and copy it
v
y

docs.title: Saving and Quitting
docs.text:
• Save and Quit: :wq or :x
  • Save: :w
  • Quit Without Saving: :q!

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Save changes and exit
:wq

docs.title: Searching and Replacing
docs.text:
• Search: /search_term
  • Replace: :s/old/new/g (for current line), :%s/old/new/g (for entire file)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Search for 'example' in the file
/example

# Replace 'foo' with 'bar' in the entire file
:%s/foo/bar/g

docs.title: Show Line Numbers
docs.text:
To show line numbers, use:

:set number

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Enable line numbers
:set number

docs.title: Split Windows
docs.text:
• Horizontal Split: :split <file>
  • Vertical Split: :vsplit <file>
  • Navigate Between Splits: Ctrl + w, then use h, j, k, l

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Split window horizontally and open 'file1.txt'
:split file1.txt

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: vim is a versatile text editor with powerful features for efficient text editing. Understanding and mastering the different modes, commands, and shortcuts will enhance your productivity. For more detailed information and advanced features, refer to the Vim Documentation.

docs.title: File & Directory
docs.text:
Explore the essentials of file and directory management, including commands for creating, deleting, and navigating the file system.

  • File and Directory Management - Detailed guide on managing files and directories effectively using various Linux commands
  • File Permissions - Learn how to manage file permissions to control access and secure your files.
  • File Viewing and Editing - Techniques and tools for viewing and editing files in Linux.

docs.title: Linux File and Directory Management Commands
Overview
docs.text: Linux provides a set of commands for managing files and directories in the filesystem. These commands allow you to create, delete, move, and manipulate files and directories. This document covers basic and commonly used file and directory management commands.

docs.title: pwd
docs.text:
Prints the current working directory.

pwd

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
pwd
# Output: /home/user

docs.title: ls
docs.text:
Lists files and directories in the current directory.

ls

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ls
# Output: file1.txt  file2.txt  directory1

docs.title: ls -l
docs.text:
Lists files and directories with detailed information, including permissions, ownership, and size.

ls -l

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ls -l
# Output:
# -rw-r--r-- 1 user user  1234 Aug  3 10:00 file1.txt
# drwxr-xr-x 2 user user  4096 Aug  3 10:00 directory1

docs.title: ls -a
docs.text:
Lists all files, including hidden files (those starting with a dot).

ls -a

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ls -a
# Output: .  ..  .hiddenfile  file1.txt  directory1

docs.title: cd <directory>
docs.text:
Changes the current working directory to the specified directory.

cd <directory>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
cd Documents
# Changes to the 'Documents' directory

docs.title: cd ..
docs.text:
Moves up one directory level.

cd ..

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
cd ..
# Moves up one level in the directory structure

docs.title: mkdir <directory>
docs.text:
Creates a new directory.

mkdir <directory>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
mkdir new_directory
# Creates a directory named 'new_directory'

docs.title: mkdir -p <path>
docs.text:
Creates a directory and any necessary parent directories.

mkdir -p /path/to/directory

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
mkdir -p /home/user/new_directory/subdirectory
# Creates 'new_directory' and 'subdirectory' if they do not exist

docs.title: rmdir <directory>
docs.text:
Removes an empty directory.

rmdir <directory>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
rmdir old_directory
# Removes the 'old_directory' if it is empty

docs.title: rm -r <directory>
docs.text:
Removes a directory and its contents recursively.

rm -r <directory>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
rm -r old_directory
# Removes 'old_directory' and all files and subdirectories within it

docs.title: touch <file>
docs.text:
Creates an empty file or updates the timestamp of an existing file.

touch <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
touch newfile.txt
# Creates an empty file named 'newfile.txt'

docs.title: rm <file>
docs.text:
Deletes a specified file.

rm <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
rm file1.txt
# Deletes the file named 'file1.txt'

docs.title: Move or Rename Files and Directories
mv <source> <destination>
docs.text:
Moves or renames a file or directory.

mv <source> <destination>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
mv file1.txt /home/user/backup/
# Moves 'file1.txt' to the 'backup' directory

docs.title: mv oldname.txt newname.txt
docs.text:
Renames a file or directory.

mv oldname.txt newname.txt

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
mv oldname.txt newname.txt
# Renames 'oldname.txt' to 'newname.txt'

docs.title: cp <source> <destination>
docs.text:
Copies a file or directory to the specified destination.

cp <source> <destination>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
cp file1.txt /home/user/backup/
# Copies 'file1.txt' to the 'backup' directory

docs.title: cp -r <source> <destination>
docs.text:
Copies a directory and its contents recursively.

cp -r <source> <destination>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
cp -r directory1 /home/user/backup/
# Copies 'directory1' and all its contents to the 'backup' directory

docs.title: cat <file>
docs.text:
Displays the content of a file.

cat <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
cat file1.txt
# Displays the content of 'file1.txt'

docs.title: less <file>
docs.text:
Allows you to view file content one page at a time.

less <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
less file1.txt
# Displays the content of 'file1.txt' one page at a time

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux provides powerful commands for managing files and directories, including creating, deleting, moving, and viewing files. Understanding these commands allows for efficient navigation and manipulation of the filesystem. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: File permissions in Linux control the access to files and directories. Permissions determine who can read, write, or execute files. This document covers basic commands for viewing and modifying file permissions.

docs.title: ls -l
docs.text:
Lists files and directories with detailed information, including permissions.

ls -l

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ls -l
# Output: Lists files and directories with permissions, owner, group, size, and modification date
# Example output:
# -rwxr-xr-- 1 user group 1234 Aug  3 10:00 example.txt

docs.title: Understanding File Permissions
docs.text:
File permissions are represented by a string of 10 characters:

-rwxr-xr--
  • File Type: - (regular file), d (directory), l (symlink)
  • Owner Permissions: rwx (read, write, execute)
  • Group Permissions: r-x (read, execute)
  • Others Permissions: r-- (read)

docs.title: chmod
docs.text:
Changes the permissions of a file or directory.

chmod [options] <permissions> <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
chmod 755 example.txt
# Sets the permissions of 'example.txt' to rwxr-xr-x (owner: read, write, execute; group and others: read, execute)

docs.title: Numeric Mode
docs.text:
• 7: rwx (read, write, execute)
  • 6: rw- (read, write)
  • 5: r-x (read, execute)
  • 4: r-- (read)
  • 3: wx- (write, execute)
  • 2: w-- (write)
  • 1: --x (execute)
  • 0: --- (no permissions)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
chmod 644 example.txt
# Sets the permissions of 'example.txt' to rw-r--r-- (owner: read, write; group and others: read)

docs.title: Symbolic Mode
docs.text:
• u: user (owner)
  • g: group
  • o: others
  • a: all

Use + to add permissions, - to remove, and = to set exact permissions.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
chmod u+x example.txt
# Adds execute permission for the owner

chmod go-w example.txt
# Removes write permission for group and others

docs.title: chown
docs.text:
Changes the owner and/or group of a file or directory.

sudo chown [owner][:group] <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo chown john:admins example.txt
# Changes the owner of 'example.txt' to 'john' and the group to 'admins'

docs.title: chgrp
docs.text:
Changes the group ownership of a file or directory.

sudo chgrp <group> <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo chgrp admins example.txt
# Changes the group ownership of 'example.txt' to 'admins'

docs.title: Setuid (Set User ID)
docs.text:
When set on an executable file, the process runs with the permissions of the file's owner.

chmod u+s <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
chmod u+s /usr/bin/someprogram
# Sets the setuid bit on 'someprogram'

docs.title: Setgid (Set Group ID)
docs.text:
When set on a directory, new files and directories inherit the group of the directory.

chmod g+s <directory>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
chmod g+s /var/shared
# Sets the setgid bit on the '/var/shared' directory

docs.title: Sticky Bit
docs.text:
When set on a directory, only the file owner can delete files within that directory.

chmod +t <directory>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
chmod +t /tmp
# Sets the sticky bit on the '/tmp' directory

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Understanding and managing file permissions is crucial for maintaining security and proper access control in Linux. These commands allow you to view and modify permissions, ownership, and special attributes of files and directories. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Linux File Viewing and Editing Commands
Overview
docs.text: Linux provides several commands for viewing and editing files. These commands allow you to read, search, and modify file content from the command line. This document covers basic and commonly used file viewing and editing commands.

docs.title: cat
docs.text:
Displays the entire content of a file.

cat <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
cat file1.txt
# Output: Displays the content of 'file1.txt'

docs.title: less
docs.text:
Displays file content one page at a time. Allows for navigation and searching within the file.

less <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
less file1.txt
# Output: Displays the content of 'file1.txt' one page at a time
# Use 'q' to quit

docs.title: more
docs.text:
Displays file content one page at a time, similar to less, but with fewer features.

more <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
more file1.txt
# Output: Displays the content of 'file1.txt' one page at a time
# Use 'q' to quit

docs.title: head
docs.text:
Displays the first few lines of a file (default is 10 lines).

head <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
head file1.txt
# Output: Displays the first 10 lines of 'file1.txt'

docs.title: head -n <number> <file>
docs.text:
Displays the first <number> lines of a file.

head -n <number> <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
head -n 20 file1.txt
# Output: Displays the first 20 lines of 'file1.txt'

docs.title: tail
docs.text:
Displays the last few lines of a file (default is 10 lines).

tail <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
tail file1.txt
# Output: Displays the last 10 lines of 'file1.txt'

docs.title: tail -n <number> <file>
docs.text:
Displays the last <number> lines of a file.

tail -n <number> <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
tail -n 20 file1.txt
# Output: Displays the last 20 lines of 'file1.txt'

docs.title: grep
docs.text:
Searches for a specific pattern within a file.

grep "<pattern>" <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
grep "error" log.txt
# Output: Displays lines containing 'error' in 'log.txt'

docs.title: find
docs.text:
Searches for files and directories based on criteria.

find <path> -name "<filename>"

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
find /home/user/ -name "*.txt"
# Output: Finds all '.txt' files in '/home/user/' directory

docs.title: nano
docs.text:
A simple, user-friendly text editor for the command line.

nano <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nano file1.txt
# Opens 'file1.txt' in the nano editor for editing
# Use 'Ctrl + X' to exit, 'Y' to confirm changes, 'N' to discard changes

docs.title: vim
docs.text:
A powerful text editor with a steep learning curve but extensive capabilities.

vim <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
vim file1.txt
# Opens 'file1.txt' in the vim editor for editing
# Use ':wq' to save and exit, ':q!' to exit without saving

docs.title: vi
docs.text:
An older text editor similar to vim, often available by default.

vi <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
vi file1.txt
# Opens 'file1.txt' in the vi editor for editing
# Use ':wq' to save and exit, ':q!' to exit without saving

docs.title: sed
docs.text:
A stream editor for filtering and transforming text.

sed 's/<pattern>/<replacement>/' <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sed 's/oldtext/newtext/' file1.txt
# Replaces 'oldtext' with 'newtext' in 'file1.txt'

docs.title: awk
docs.text:
A programming language for pattern scanning and processing.

awk '{print $1}' <file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
awk '{print $1}' file1.txt
# Prints the first column of 'file1.txt'

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux provides a range of commands for viewing and editing files, from simple viewers like cat and less to powerful editors like vim and nano. Understanding these commands helps manage and manipulate file content effectively from the command line. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Firewall & Networking
docs.text:
Comprehensive guide on setting up and managing firewalls and network configurations.

  • Firewalls and Networking - Detailed guide on managing firewalls and network connections.
  • Network Configuration and Monitoring - Understand network configurations and how to monitor network activity and performance.
  • SSH - Secure Shell (SSH) guide for remote login and secure communication over unsecured networks.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Linux provides various tools for managing network configurations and firewalls. This document covers basic and commonly used commands for network management and firewall configuration.

docs.title: ifconfig
docs.text:
Displays or configures network interfaces.

ifconfig [interface]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ifconfig eth0
# Displays the configuration for the 'eth0' network interface

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ifconfig eth0 up
# Brings up the 'eth0' network interface

docs.title: ip
docs.text: A more modern tool for managing network interfaces, routes, and addresses.

docs.title: Show Network Interfaces
docs.text: ip addr show

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ip addr show
# Displays detailed information about all network interfaces

docs.title: Assign an IP Address
docs.text: sudo ip addr add <IP_address>/<netmask> dev <interface>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev eth0
# Assigns the IP address 192.168.1.100 to the 'eth0' interface

docs.title: Bring Up/Down an Interface
docs.text:
sudo ip link set <interface> up
sudo ip link set <interface> down

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo ip link set eth0 up
# Brings up the 'eth0' interface

docs.title: netstat
docs.text:
Displays network connections, routing tables, interface statistics, and more.

netstat [options]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
netstat -tuln
# Displays listening TCP and UDP ports with numeric addresses

docs.title: ss
docs.text:
A utility to investigate sockets and network connections, a modern replacement for netstat.

ss [options]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ss -tuln
# Displays listening TCP and UDP sockets with numeric addresses

docs.title: ping
docs.text:
Sends ICMP ECHO_REQUEST packets to network hosts.

ping [options] <host>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ping google.com
# Pings 'google.com' to check network connectivity

docs.title: traceroute
docs.text:
Displays the route packets take to a network host.

traceroute <host>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
traceroute google.com
# Shows the path taken to reach 'google.com'

docs.title: nslookup
docs.text:
Queries DNS to obtain domain name or IP address mapping.

nslookup <domain>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nslookup google.com
# Queries DNS for information about 'google.com'

docs.title: route
docs.text:
Displays or modifies the IP routing table.

route [options]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
route -n
# Displays the IP routing table with numeric addresses

docs.title: ip route
docs.text:
Displays and manages the routing table.

ip route [options]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ip route show
# Displays the current routing table

docs.title: iptables
docs.text: Configures and manages firewall rules.

docs.title: List Rules
docs.text: sudo iptables -L

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo iptables -L
# Lists all current firewall rules

docs.title: Add Rule
docs.text: sudo iptables -A <chain> -p <protocol> --dport <port> -j <target>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo iptables -A INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT
# Allows incoming TCP connections on port 22 (SSH)

docs.title: Delete Rule
docs.text: sudo iptables -D <chain> -p <protocol> --dport <port> -j <target>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo iptables -D INPUT -p tcp --dport 22 -j ACCEPT
# Deletes the rule allowing incoming TCP connections on port 22

docs.title: ufw
docs.text: Uncomplicated Firewall (UFW) is a user-friendly front-end for managing firewall rules.

docs.title: Enable UFW
docs.text: sudo ufw enable

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo ufw enable
# Enables the UFW firewall

docs.title: Allow a Port
docs.text: sudo ufw allow <port>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo ufw allow 22
# Allows incoming connections on port 22 (SSH)

docs.title: Deny a Port
docs.text: sudo ufw deny <port>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo ufw deny 80
# Denies incoming connections on port 80 (HTTP)

docs.title: Check UFW Status
docs.text: sudo ufw status

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo ufw status
# Displays the current status and rules of UFW

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux provides a robust set of tools for managing network configurations and firewall rules. Mastering these commands helps in monitoring and securing network traffic, configuring network interfaces, and troubleshooting network issues. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Linux Network Configuration and Monitoring Commands
Overview
docs.text: Linux provides a variety of commands for configuring and monitoring network interfaces and connections. These commands are essential for managing network settings, diagnosing network issues, and ensuring proper connectivity. This document covers basic and commonly used network configuration and monitoring commands.

docs.title: ip
docs.text: A powerful tool for configuring network interfaces, routing, and tunnels.

docs.title: Display Network Interfaces
docs.text: ip addr

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ip addr
# Output: Lists all network interfaces with their IP addresses and other details

docs.title: Display Routing Table
docs.text: ip route

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ip route
# Output: Displays the current routing table

docs.title: Add an IP Address
docs.text: sudo ip addr add <ip_address>/<subnet> dev <interface>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev eth0
# Adds the IP address 192.168.1.100 with subnet 24 to the interface 'eth0'

docs.title: Delete an IP Address
docs.text: sudo ip addr del <ip_address>/<subnet> dev <interface>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo ip addr del 192.168.1.100/24 dev eth0
# Removes the IP address 192.168.1.100 from the interface 'eth0'

docs.title: ifconfig
docs.text:
Displays and configures network interfaces. Note: ifconfig is deprecated in favor of ip.

ifconfig

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ifconfig
# Output: Displays network interface configuration

docs.title: nmcli
docs.text: Command-line interface for NetworkManager, used to manage network connections.

docs.title: List Network Connections
docs.text: nmcli connection show

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nmcli connection show
# Output: Lists all network connections managed by NetworkManager

docs.title: Connect to a Network
docs.text: nmcli connection up <connection_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nmcli connection up my-wifi
# Connects to the network named 'my-wifi'

docs.title: Disconnect from a Network
docs.text: nmcli connection down <connection_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nmcli connection down my-wifi
# Disconnects from the network named 'my-wifi'

docs.title: ping
docs.text:
Sends ICMP ECHO_REQUEST packets to a network host to check connectivity.

ping <hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ping google.com
# Output: Sends packets to 'google.com' to check connectivity

docs.title: traceroute
docs.text:
Displays the route packets take to a network host.

traceroute <hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
traceroute google.com
# Output: Shows the route taken by packets to reach 'google.com'

docs.title: netstat
docs.text: Displays network connections, routing tables, and interface statistics. Note: netstat is deprecated in favor of ss.

docs.title: Display All Connections
docs.text: netstat -a

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
netstat -a
# Output: Lists all network connections and listening ports

docs.title: ss
docs.text: Displays detailed information about network sockets.

docs.title: Display All Connections
docs.text: ss -a

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ss -a
# Output: Lists all network connections and listening ports

docs.title: tcpdump
docs.text:
Captures and analyzes network packets.

sudo tcpdump

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo tcpdump -i eth0
# Captures packets on the 'eth0' interface

docs.title: iftop
docs.text:
Displays bandwidth usage on network interfaces.

sudo iftop

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo iftop
# Output: Displays real-time bandwidth usage on all network interfaces
# Use 'q' to quit

docs.title: nmap
docs.text:
Network scanning tool used to discover hosts and services on a network.

nmap <hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nmap 192.168.1.1
# Scans the IP address 192.168.1.1 for open ports and services

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux provides a comprehensive set of commands for configuring and monitoring network interfaces and connections. These commands are essential for managing network settings, diagnosing issues, and ensuring network connectivity. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: SSH (Secure Shell) is a protocol used to securely access and manage remote systems over a network. The SSH suite of commands provides a variety of tools for connecting to, configuring, and managing remote systems. This document covers basic and commonly used SSH commands.

docs.title: ssh
docs.text:
Used to securely connect to a remote machine.

ssh <user>@<hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh john@192.168.1.100
# Connects to the remote host 192.168.1.100 as user 'john'

docs.title: ssh-keygen
docs.text:
Generates a new SSH key pair.

ssh-keygen

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh-keygen
# Prompts to generate a new SSH key pair; saves the private key and public key in the default location (~/.ssh/)

docs.title: ssh-copy-id
docs.text:
Copies your SSH public key to a remote host's authorized keys.

ssh-copy-id <user>@<hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh-copy-id john@192.168.1.100
# Copies the public key to the remote host to enable passwordless login for user 'john'

docs.title: scp
docs.text:
Securely copies files between hosts over SSH.

scp <source> <user>@<hostname_or_ip>:<destination>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
scp localfile.txt john@192.168.1.100:/home/john/
# Copies 'localfile.txt' from the local machine to the '/home/john/' directory on the remote host

docs.title: sftp
docs.text:
Secure File Transfer Protocol for transferring files over SSH.

sftp <user>@<hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sftp john@192.168.1.100
# Opens an SFTP session with the remote host

docs.title: ssh-add
docs.text:
Adds SSH private keys to the SSH authentication agent.

ssh-add <key_file>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa
# Adds the private key 'id_rsa' to the SSH agent for authentication

docs.title: ssh-agent
docs.text:
Manages SSH keys and handles authentication for SSH sessions.

eval $(ssh-agent)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
eval $(ssh-agent)
# Starts the SSH agent and sets environment variables for the current session

docs.title: ssh -i
docs.text:
Specifies a private key file to use for authentication.

ssh -i <private_key_file> <user>@<hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa john@192.168.1.100
# Connects to the remote host using the specified private key file

docs.title: ssh -p
docs.text:
Specifies a port number for the SSH connection.

ssh -p <port_number> <user>@<hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh -p 2222 john@192.168.1.100
# Connects to the remote host on port 2222

docs.title: ssh -L
docs.text:
Creates a local port forwarding.

ssh -L <local_port>:<remote_host>:<remote_port> <user>@<hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh -L 8080:localhost:80 john@192.168.1.100
# Forwards local port 8080 to port 80 on the remote host through SSH

docs.title: ssh -R
docs.text:
Creates a remote port forwarding.

ssh -R <remote_port>:<local_host>:<local_port> <user>@<hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh -R 9090:localhost:80 john@192.168.1.100
# Forwards remote port 9090 to port 80 on the local machine through SSH

docs.title: ssh -C
docs.text:
Enables compression for the SSH connection.

ssh -C <user>@<hostname_or_ip>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ssh -C john@192.168.1.100
# Connects to the remote host with compression enabled

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The SSH suite of commands provides powerful tools for securely managing and transferring data between systems. By mastering these commands, you can effectively perform remote administration and file transfers while maintaining secure connections. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: System Management
docs.text:
Learn about system monitoring, process management, and performance tuning to maintain a healthy Linux environment.

  • System Information - Retrieve and interpret various system information and hardware details.
  • Disk Management - Learn about managing disks, partitions, and filesystems in Linux.
  • User and Group Management - Manage users and groups, including creation, deletion, and permission settings.
  • Package Management - Manage software packages, including installation, updates, and removal.
  • Process Management - Learn about monitoring and controlling processes in Linux.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Linux provides various commands for managing disks and filesystems. These commands allow you to view disk usage, partition disks, format filesystems, and more. This document covers basic and commonly used disk management commands.

docs.title: df
docs.text:
Displays information about disk space usage on filesystems.

df [options] [file...]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
df -h
# Output: Displays disk space usage in human-readable format (e.g., GB, MB)

docs.title: du
docs.text:
Displays disk usage for files and directories.

du [options] [directory...]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
du -sh /home/user
# Output: Shows the total disk usage of the directory '/home/user' in human-readable format

docs.title: lsblk
docs.text:
Lists information about all available block devices.

lsblk [options]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
lsblk
# Output: Displays a list of block devices, including partitions and their mount points

docs.title: fdisk
docs.text:
Partition table manipulator for creating, deleting, and managing disk partitions.

sudo fdisk /dev/sdX

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo fdisk /dev/sda
# Opens fdisk to manage partitions on the /dev/sda disk

docs.title: Common fdisk Commands
docs.text:
• List partitions: p
  • Create a new partition: n
  • Delete a partition: d
  • Write changes: w
  • Quit without saving: q

docs.title: parted
docs.text:
A tool for managing disk partitions.

sudo parted /dev/sdX

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo parted /dev/sda
# Opens parted to manage partitions on the /dev/sda disk

docs.title: Common parted Commands
docs.text:
• Print partition table: print
  • Create a new partition: mkpart
  • Delete a partition: rm
  • Resize a partition: resizepart
  • Quit: quit

docs.title: mkfs
docs.text:
Creates a filesystem on a disk or partition.

sudo mkfs -t <filesystem_type> /dev/sdXn

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo mkfs -t ext4 /dev/sda1
# Creates an ext4 filesystem on the /dev/sda1 partition

docs.title: fsck
docs.text:
Checks and repairs a filesystem.

sudo fsck [options] /dev/sdXn

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo fsck /dev/sda1
# Checks and repairs the filesystem on /dev/sda1

docs.title: mount
docs.text:
Mounts a filesystem to a directory.

sudo mount [options] /dev/sdXn <mount_point>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo mount /dev/sda1 /mnt
# Mounts the filesystem on /dev/sda1 to the /mnt directory

docs.title: umount
docs.text:
Unmounts a filesystem from a directory.

sudo umount <mount_point>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo umount /mnt
# Unmounts the filesystem from the /mnt directory

docs.title: lsblk (again)
docs.text:
Lists block devices and their mount points.

lsblk -f

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
lsblk -f
# Output: Displays filesystem type and labels along with block device information

docs.title: ncdu
docs.text:
A disk usage analyzer with a text-based user interface.

ncdu [directory]

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ncdu /home/user
# Opens ncdu to analyze disk usage in the '/home/user' directory

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux offers a comprehensive set of commands for managing disks and filesystems. Understanding these commands helps in monitoring disk usage, partitioning disks, and maintaining filesystems effectively. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Linux distributions use different package managers to handle software installation, updates, and removal. This document covers basic and commonly used package management commands for various package managers.

docs.title: apt
docs.text: The Advanced Package Tool (APT) is used for managing packages in Debian-based distributions.

docs.title: Update Package List
docs.text: sudo apt update

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo apt update
# Updates the package list from repositories

docs.title: Upgrade Installed Packages
docs.text: sudo apt upgrade

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo apt upgrade
# Upgrades all installed packages to their latest versions

docs.title: Install a Package
docs.text: sudo apt install <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo apt install vim
# Installs the 'vim' text editor

docs.title: Remove a Package
docs.text: sudo apt remove <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo apt remove vim
# Removes the 'vim' text editor

docs.title: Search for a Package
docs.text: apt search <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
apt search vim
# Searches for packages related to 'vim'

docs.title: Show Package Details
docs.text: apt show <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
apt show vim
# Displays detailed information about the 'vim' package

docs.title: yum
docs.text: The Yellowdog Updater, Modified (YUM) is used for managing packages in older Red Hat-based distributions.

docs.title: Update Package List and System
docs.text: sudo yum update

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo yum update
# Updates the package list and upgrades all installed packages

docs.title: Install a Package
docs.text: sudo yum install <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo yum install vim
# Installs the 'vim' text editor

docs.title: Remove a Package
docs.text: sudo yum remove <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo yum remove vim
# Removes the 'vim' text editor

docs.title: Search for a Package
docs.text: yum search <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
yum search vim
# Searches for packages related to 'vim'

docs.title: Show Package Details
docs.text: yum info <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
yum info vim
# Displays detailed information about the 'vim' package

docs.title: dnf
docs.text: The Dandified YUM (DNF) is used for managing packages in newer Red Hat-based distributions.

docs.title: Update Package List and System
docs.text: sudo dnf update

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo dnf update
# Updates the package list and upgrades all installed packages

docs.title: Install a Package
docs.text: sudo dnf install <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo dnf install vim
# Installs the 'vim' text editor

docs.title: Remove a Package
docs.text: sudo dnf remove <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo dnf remove vim
# Removes the 'vim' text editor

docs.title: Search for a Package
docs.text: dnf search <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
dnf search vim
# Searches for packages related to 'vim'

docs.title: Show Package Details
docs.text: dnf info <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
dnf info vim
# Displays detailed information about the 'vim' package

docs.title: zypper
docs.text: The command-line interface for managing packages in SUSE-based distributions.

docs.title: Update Package List and System
docs.text:
sudo zypper refresh
sudo zypper update

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo zypper refresh
sudo zypper update
# Refreshes package list and upgrades all installed packages

docs.title: Install a Package
docs.text: sudo zypper install <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo zypper install vim
# Installs the 'vim' text editor

docs.title: Remove a Package
docs.text: sudo zypper remove <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo zypper remove vim
# Removes the 'vim' text editor

docs.title: Search for a Package
docs.text: zypper search <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
zypper search vim
# Searches for packages related to 'vim'

docs.title: Show Package Details
docs.text: zypper info <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
zypper info vim
# Displays detailed information about the 'vim' package

docs.title: rpm
docs.text: The RPM Package Manager is used for managing packages in RPM-based distributions.

docs.title: Install a Package
docs.text: sudo rpm -i <package_file.rpm>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo rpm -i vim-8.2.0-1.x86_64.rpm
# Installs the 'vim' package from the RPM file

docs.title: Remove a Package
docs.text: sudo rpm -e <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo rpm -e vim
# Removes the 'vim' package

docs.title: Query Package Information
docs.text: rpm -q <package_name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
rpm -q vim
# Queries information about the 'vim' package

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux offers various package management tools depending on the distribution used. Understanding these commands helps in efficiently managing software installations, updates, and removals. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Linux provides several commands for managing processes, which include starting, stopping, and monitoring processes. These commands are essential for controlling and managing the execution of programs and tasks on a Linux system. This document covers basic and commonly used process management commands.

docs.title: ps
docs.text:
Displays information about active processes.

ps

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ps
# Output: Lists processes running in the current shell

docs.title: ps aux
docs.text:
Displays a detailed list of all running processes, including those from other users.

ps aux

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
ps aux
# Output: Detailed list of all running processes

docs.title: top
docs.text:
Displays a dynamic, real-time view of system processes.

top

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
top
# Output: Real-time display of active processes and system resource usage
# Use 'q' to quit

docs.title: htop
docs.text:
An interactive process viewer similar to top, but with a more user-friendly interface.

htop

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
htop
# Output: Interactive display of processes with user-friendly interface
# Use 'q' to quit

docs.title: pgrep
docs.text:
Searches for processes by name or other attributes.

pgrep <name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
pgrep ssh
# Output: Lists process IDs of processes matching 'ssh'

docs.title: kill
docs.text:
Sends a signal to a process, commonly used to terminate it.

kill <PID>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
kill 1234
# Sends the default SIGTERM signal to the process with PID 1234

docs.title: kill -9
docs.text:
Forcibly terminates a process.

kill -9 <PID>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
kill -9 1234
# Sends the SIGKILL signal to the process with PID 1234, forcibly terminating it

docs.title: pkill
docs.text:
Sends a signal to processes by name.

pkill <name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
pkill firefox
# Sends the default SIGTERM signal to all processes named 'firefox'

docs.title: killall
docs.text:
Sends a signal to all processes with a specific name.

killall <name>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
killall firefox
# Sends the default SIGTERM signal to all processes named 'firefox'

docs.title: nice
docs.text:
Runs a command with a specified priority level.

nice -n <priority> <command>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
nice -n 10 gzip largefile.txt
# Runs 'gzip largefile.txt' with a priority level of 10

docs.title: renice
docs.text:
Changes the priority of a running process.

renice <priority> -p <PID>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
renice 5 -p 1234
# Changes the priority of the process with PID 1234 to 5

docs.title: &
docs.text:
Runs a command in the background.

command &

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sleep 60 &
# Runs the 'sleep 60' command in the background

docs.title: jobs
docs.text:
Lists all background jobs.

jobs

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
jobs
# Output: Lists background jobs and their job numbers

docs.title: fg
docs.text:
Brings a background job to the foreground.

fg %<job_number>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
fg %1
# Brings the background job with job number 1 to the foreground

docs.title: bg
docs.text:
Resumes a suspended job in the background.

bg %<job_number>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
bg %1
# Resumes the suspended job with job number 1 in the background

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux offers a variety of commands for managing processes, from displaying and monitoring to controlling and prioritizing. Understanding these commands helps effectively manage and troubleshoot processes on a Linux system. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Linux provides a range of commands to gather information about the system's hardware, software, and overall status. These commands are useful for monitoring and troubleshooting system performance and configuration. This document covers basic and commonly used system information commands.

docs.title: uname
docs.text:
Displays system information.

uname

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
uname
# Output: Displays the kernel name (e.g., Linux)

docs.title: uname -a
docs.text:
Displays all available system information, including kernel version and system architecture.

uname -a

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
uname -a
# Output: Linux hostname 5.4.0-42-generic #46-Ubuntu SMP Fri Sep 25 13:00:00 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

docs.title: hostname
docs.text:
Displays or sets the system's hostname.

hostname

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
hostname
# Output: Displays the current hostname of the system

docs.title: hostnamectl
docs.text:
Displays or changes the system's hostname and other system information.

hostnamectl

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
hostnamectl
# Output: Provides detailed information about the system's hostname, operating system, and hardware

docs.title: lscpu
docs.text:
Displays detailed information about the CPU architecture.

lscpu

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
lscpu
# Output: Displays CPU architecture information including number of CPUs, model name, and more

docs.title: lsblk
docs.text:
Lists information about all available block devices.

lsblk

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
lsblk
# Output: Lists block devices and their mount points, sizes, and types

docs.title: lspci
docs.text:
Lists all PCI devices on the system.

lspci

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
lspci
# Output: Lists PCI devices such as graphics cards, network adapters, etc.

docs.title: lsusb
docs.text:
Lists all USB devices connected to the system.

lsusb

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
lsusb
# Output: Lists USB devices connected to the system along with their vendor and product IDs

docs.title: dmidecode
docs.text:
Displays information about the system's hardware as described in the BIOS.

sudo dmidecode

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo dmidecode
# Output: Provides detailed information about hardware components, such as memory, CPU, and motherboard

docs.title: free
docs.text:
Displays information about system memory usage.

free

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
free
# Output: Displays memory usage, including total, used, and free memory

docs.title: df
docs.text:
Displays information about disk space usage for mounted filesystems.

df

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
df
# Output: Displays disk space usage for each mounted filesystem

docs.title: du
docs.text:
Displays disk usage of files and directories.

du <directory>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
du /home/user
# Output: Displays disk usage for the '/home/user' directory

docs.title: top
docs.text:
Displays real-time system performance and process information.

top

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
top
# Output: Displays a real-time, interactive view of system processes and resource usage
# Use 'q' to quit

docs.title: htop
docs.text:
An enhanced version of top with a more user-friendly interface.

htop

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
htop
# Output: Provides an interactive, user-friendly view of system processes and resource usage
# Use 'q' to quit

docs.title: uptime
docs.text:
Displays how long the system has been running, along with the number of users and load average.

uptime

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
uptime
# Output: Displays system uptime, number of users, and load averages

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux provides a variety of commands to gather detailed system information, from hardware details and disk usage to real-time performance metrics. Understanding these commands helps in monitoring and maintaining system health. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.

docs.title: Linux User and Group Management Commands
Overview
docs.text: Linux provides a set of commands for managing users and groups. These commands allow you to create, modify, delete, and view users and groups on the system. This document covers basic and commonly used user and group management commands.

docs.title: adduser or useradd
docs.text:
Creates a new user.

sudo adduser <username>
# or
sudo useradd <username>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo adduser john
# Creates a new user named 'john'

docs.title: usermod
docs.text:
Modifies an existing user's account details.

sudo usermod <options> <username>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo usermod -aG sudo john
# Adds the user 'john' to the 'sudo' group

docs.title: deluser or userdel
docs.text:
Deletes a user account.

sudo deluser <username>
# or
sudo userdel <username>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo deluser john
# Deletes the user 'john' but keeps the home directory

docs.title: passwd
docs.text:
Changes a user's password.

sudo passwd <username>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo passwd john
# Prompts to change the password for the user 'john'

docs.title: id
docs.text:
Displays information about a user.

id <username>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
id john
# Output: Displays user ID (UID), group ID (GID), and group memberships for 'john'

docs.title: whoami
docs.text:
Displays the username of the current user.

whoami

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
whoami
# Output: Displays the current logged-in username

docs.title: addgroup or groupadd
docs.text:
Creates a new group.

sudo addgroup <groupname>
# or
sudo groupadd <groupname>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo addgroup developers
# Creates a new group named 'developers'

docs.title: delgroup or groupdel
docs.text:
Deletes a group.

sudo delgroup <groupname>
# or
sudo groupdel <groupname>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo delgroup developers
# Deletes the group named 'developers'

docs.title: gpasswd
docs.text:
Modifies group memberships and settings.

sudo gpasswd -a <username> <groupname>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
sudo gpasswd -a john developers
# Adds the user 'john' to the 'developers' group

docs.title: groups
docs.text:
Displays the groups that a user belongs to.

groups <username>

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
groups john
# Output: Displays the groups that the user 'john' belongs to

docs.title: getent
docs.text:
Displays entries from databases configured in /etc/nsswitch.conf, including users and groups.

getent passwd

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
getent passwd
# Output: Displays all user accounts in the system

docs.title: cat /etc/passwd
docs.text:
Displays the contents of the user account database file.

cat /etc/passwd

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
cat /etc/passwd
# Output: Displays user account information including username, UID, GID, home directory, and shell

docs.title: cat /etc/group
docs.text:
Displays the contents of the group database file.

cat /etc/group

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
cat /etc/group
# Output: Displays group information including group name, GID, and group members

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Linux offers a range of commands for managing users and groups, including creating, modifying, and deleting accounts and groups. Understanding these commands helps in effectively managing user and group permissions on a Linux system. For more detailed information on each command, refer to the Linux manual pages.
